title: I have a Eastern Long-necked Turtle and it’s shell is starting to get soft. I am starting to worry about conditions like shell rot and infections as it spends most of its time in the water. Any suggestions? - Quora

response.answer_text: This sounds like either a) shell rot or b) lack of calcium. If it’s a) you would see brown spots that are soft, not the whole shell. You can correct this by cleaning the turtle with a toothbrush, dust it down with a little dry iodine spray and keep his surroundings scrupulously clean, it can be reversed. if it’s b) then you need to get more calcium into your turtle. There are a number of ways of doing this. The vet can give you supplements, but it’s better to try and do it naturally. Some turtles will eat cuttlefish bone that you can get from the pet store, in the pet bird aisle. Mine prefer hard boiled eggs with the shell left on. They will eat the whole thing, shell and all. It’s not unusual for turtles to prefer to spend most of their lives in water, but a dry place for them to bask should always be available. At the moment I have a little common musk boy in an emergency tank and he basks on top of a little laundry basket. In either case I would show your turtle to a reptile vet, just to rule out anything more serious. Good luck!
